description: Belgium: Authorities in Antwerp announced on Monday, July 27, that a 23:30 to 06:00 curfew will be imposed in the province of Antwerp. The new measures will come into effect on July 29 and are set to last for at least four weeks.

Belgium: Authorities in Antwerp announced on Monday, July 27, that a 23:30 to 06:00 curfew will be imposed in the province of Antwerp. The new measures will come into effect on July 29 and are set to last for at least four weeks. 
Authorities in Antwerp have suspended the city's 23:30-06:00 curfew from Aug. 7, for the duration of an ongoing heatwave.

description: The authorities in Belgium have decided to introduce a COVID-19 curfew in the country from October 19. The measures are set to last for one month, but the situation will be evaluated after two weeks.
Since Wednesday 18 March, Belgium has banned non-essential travel abroad until the end of lockdown (5 April). Goods and services can still be transported across the border.

Since Wednesday 18 March, Belgium has banned non-essential travel abroad until the end of lockdown (5 April). Goods and services can still be transported across the border.

The Schengen external borders closure has been extended until May 15th 2020. This prohibits entry into Belgium to most non-EEA travellers.

description:
Since May 30th Belgium  has introduced several measures limiting the passage at its borders (from Belgium and into Belgium) to professional and essential journeys.
The following movements are considered an essential movement :

professional travel
co-parenting arrangements
visit a family member in a neighbouring country (since 05/30/2020)
provide assistance to a vulnerable person living abroad
attend a family funeral
picking up someone in your family at an airport in one of our neighbouring countries
take care of your animals that are abroad
shopping in a neighbouring country (since 30/05/2020)

This list only applies to movements within the EU, Schengen zone and United Kingdom.
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: 16 April: Belgium's land borders with other Schengen Area nations remain open, though nonessential travel to or out of the country is prohibited.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Belgium as of June 15th, Belgium will open its borders for travel to and from the European Union, including the United Kingdom and the four other Schengen countries (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Iceland and Norway). However, it is up to each country to decide whether to open its borders. To know the situation in the country of destination, it is therefore advisable to consult the website of the FPS Foreign Affairs. The conditions for travel outside of Europe have yet to be defined in light of the evolution of discussions at European level.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
May 4th: Belgium will introduce a new contact tracing strategy, from 11 May onward. The strategy looks as follows:

When a patient is tested, the doctor performing the test will ask the patient to record their contacts over the last few days.

From the middle of this week, patients infected with Covid-19 will be contacted by a call centre to ask who they have been in close contact with over the past few days. The form they filled out may be helpful during this call. People who have recently been in close contact with an infected person will also be called by the call centre. Their state of health will be assessed and, on that basis, they will be asked to take the necessary measures.

The infected patients’ general practitioner will already ask them whether they have been in close contact with certain people, such as people living in the same household. In this case, the general practitioner can issue a quarantine certificate for these people, even if the individuals concerned do not (yet) show symptoms and are fit for work. Individuals who have been issued with such a quarantine certificate must comply with the isolation measures. They can, however, work from home.

Under certain, strictly defined conditions this quarantine certificate may also be issued by the call centre under the responsibility of a hygiene inspector.

Belgium, May 7: The following content for a “Guide to the opening of trade” was compiled. 
In catering establishments: Ensure complete cleaning and disinfection of the materials and areas used by staff and guests.
In Belgium, as of June 8th it will be possible to travel within Belgium for trips lasting one or more days.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description:
In the Brussels Region, “non-essential” visits to retirement homes have been banned until 31 March as well, the authorities announced on Wednesday, 11 March.

However, the Brussels nursing homes which depend on the Flemish Community are not affected and are applying the measures announced on Tuesday, namely a limitation of visiting hours and a ban on access to children under 16.

Belgium, 11 March: In Wallonia, the authorities have banned all visits to nursing homes and assisted living facilities until 31 March in order to reduce the spread of the epidemic and protect fragile residents.

Lockdown, Belgium, 12 March: Flanders has issued a ban on visits to nursing homes to protect elderly residents from the rapid spread of the coronavirus pandemic, making it the last region in Belgium to do so.
Belgium announced that a national lockdown will go into effect on March 18th until April 5.

Belgium announced that a national lockdown will go into effect on March 18th until April 5. 
UPDATE: On March 27th, the Belgian National Security Council announced that the lockdown will be extended until April 19th with stricter enforcement of lockdown policies.
UPDATE: Belgium will be in lockdown until May 4th when it will start its 3 phase plan
link: NA ; https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/belgium-extends-coronavirus-lockdown-to-april-19/ ; SchengenVisaInfo News ; Belgium Extends Coronavirus Lockdown to April 19 ; https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/news/nsc-24-04/ ; https://www.brusselstimes.com/news/belgium-all-news/107955/107955/

description:
April 15th: Previously, no visitors were in allowed in Belgian nursing homes. From May 3rd onward, however, residents of residential facilities – i.e. rest and care homes or centres for people with disabilities – will be allowed to be visited by a pre-designated person. 
The condition is that the person in question has not shown any symptoms of the disease in the past two weeks. It must always be the same person. The residential facilities will be able to organise these visits themselves. These rules will also apply to people who live in isolation and are unable to move around.

It is unclear when this policy is slated to end.
Belgium created a new police task force responsible for enforcing lockdown in a unified manner towards civilians and businesses
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On February 2nd, 9 Belgian nationals returned from Wuhan. All nationals returning are required to quarantine for 14 days until February 16th at Neder-over-Heembeek military hospital
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)

description: People arriving in Belgium from abroad are instructed to quarantine themselves at home for 14 days from 25 March.
People arriving in Belgium are instructed to quarantine themselves at home for 14 days from 25 March.

Belgium: Since the beginning of May, all people with symptoms and close contacts of COVID-positive people are tested. The following isolation and quarantine rules apply:
• For symptomatic people: If results are positive, people have to isolate at home for at least 7 additional days after receiving their test results. If they have no symptoms at day 7, isolation can be stopped.
• For asymptomatic close contacts: Up to October 1st, if the test result was negative, close contacts must remain in quarantine for 14 days after the last risk contact.

description:
May 6th: Previously, all non-essential businesses in Belgium had to close their doors. Since May 11th, all regular stores can open again (at earlier stages, fabric stores, garden centres and DIY stores were allowed to open already).

Yet, many non-essential businesses must remain closed still. These include:
- Markets (only individual market stalls (food and non-food) will be allowed by the local authorities and at the usual locations)
- Cafes, bars, restaurants and festivity halls
- Recreational, cultural and tourist sites 
- Hairdressers, beautycians and other businesses that require physical contact

description:
May 6th: Previously, all non-essential businesses in Belgium had to close their doors. Since May 11th, all regular stores can open again (at earlier stages, fabric stores, garden centres and DIY stores were allowed to open already).

On May 13th Belgium announces that certain non-essential businesses to open their door again. These are "professions requiring close contact with customers" (e.g. beautycians) as well as markets and nature attractions like zoos.
These policy relaxations are part of Belgium's exit strategy, phase 2 and will take effect on May 18th.

The non-essential businesses must remain closed include:
- Cafes, bars, restaurants and festivity halls

description:
May 6th: Previously, all non-essential businesses in Belgium had to close their doors. Since May 11th, all regular stores can open again (at earlier stages, fabric stores, garden centres and DIY stores were allowed to open already).

On May 13th Belgium announces that certain non-essential businesses to open their door again. These are "professions requiring close contact with customers" (e.g. beautycians) as well as markets and nature attractions like zoos.
These policy relaxations are part of Belgium's exit strategy, phase 2 and will take effect on May 18th.

The non-essential businesses must remain closed include:
- Cafes, bars, restaurants and festivity halls
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
link: NA ; https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2020/05/15/corona-de-nieuwe-regels-vanaf-18-mei-in-eenvoudige-taal/ ; VRT Nieuws ; Corona: de nieuwe regels vanaf 18 mei, in eenvoudige taal

description: On 10 March the Belgian government has issued the advice to cancel indoor events with more than 1,000 people to contain the spread of the new coronavirus (Covid-19). There are no restrictions for outdoor events, but people who have a higher risk of infection are advised to avoid large crowds. The policy will last until the end of March.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: Belgium, 10 March: Concerts in Brussels attended by more than 1,000 people will be banned from Wednesday 11 March to contain the spread of the new coronavirus (Covid-19). The same measure will also apply to other indoor events, such as sports competitions or trade fairs, with more than 1,000 visitors.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description: Belgium: all recreational, cultural or folkloric and sporting events, regardless of size and whether it is a private or public meeting will be cancelled or postponed from 13 March to 3 April.

Belgium: Citizens are obliged to stay at home to avoid contact outside their families as much as possible. Gatherings are not allowed. The following measures enter into force on Wednesday, March 18 at noon and are enforced until April 5.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)

description: Belgium: From May 4th Physical activity in the open air is allowed with a maximum of two people, in addition to the people living under the same roof, provided that physical distance is always respected.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Belgium: From 10 May, every family may receive a maximum of four people - always the same - at home. To limit the number of contacts and to prevent the spread of the virus, visitors can only meet with one family.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Regarding weddings and funerals, it will be possible to receive a maximum of 30 people at ceremonies from 18 May, under certain conditions, including respecting the safety distance.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description:
Belgium: From May 18 Regular outdoor and club sports training and classes may be resumed if they respect the safety distance and a coach is present.
Groups may not exceed 20 people and sports clubs may only reopen on the condition that all measures are taken to ensure the safety of the athletes.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On Wednesday 3 June Belgium announced: Sporting and now also cultural activities organized and supervised by a responsible person are limited to 20 people from 8 June. The policy will be in effect until the 1st of July.

description: On 3 June, Belgium announced that from the 8th of June group meetings are limited to a maximum of 10 people, including children. This applies to all meetings, regardless of whether they take place at home or away from home.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description:
Belgium: Religious worship services or ideological gatherings may be resumed from 8 June, subject to the following rules, among others:
The safety distance must be maintained with a maximum of 100 people.

description:
12th of March: Belgium encourages citizens to work from home.
The instructions are as follows:
Keep working, but work from home as much as possible. Postpone meetings or organise them online. When at work, keep a distance from each other and follow the hygiene prescriptions. If possible, change working hours so that less people are at work at the same time.
Belgium: On Tuesday 17 March, additional measures were decided:  Public transport must be organized in such a way that social distancing can be guaranteed.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation

description:
15th of April: Belgium encourages citizens to work from home.
The instructions are as follows:
Keep working, but work from home as much as possible. Postpone meetings or organise them online. When at work, keep a distance from each other and follow the hygiene prescriptions. If possible, change working hours so that less people are at work at the same time.

This advice is set to last until May 3rd.

Belgium, 24 April: Covering the mouth and nose is important. This is possible with a so-called comfort mask or an alternative means of protection such as a scarf or a bandana. That will be:
compulsory on public transport for users aged 12 and older. This measure will take effect from 4 May.

Belgium, 24 April: Covering the mouth and nose is important. This is possible with a so-called comfort mask or an alternative means of protection such as a scarf or a bandana. That will be:
recommended in public places.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

Wednesday, June 3, the National Security Council, extended to include the Ministers-President, approved the transition to Phase 3 of the phase-out plan starting on 8 June. All hospitality establishments such as cafes, bars and restaurants will reopen according to a very precise protocol. The main features of this protocol include: A distance of 1.50 metres between the tables and a maximum of 10 persons per table;
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: 3 June: Belgium is starting Phase 3 of the phase-out plan starting on June 8th 2020. The hospitality industry will be allowed to open partially (gaming halls, banqueting and reception halls will not be allowed to reopen until 1 July).  Banqueting and reception halls will be allowed to operate with a maximum of 50 people present.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: 3 June: Belgium is starting Phase 3 of the phase-out plan starting on June 8th 2020. The hospitality industry will be allowed to open partially (gaming halls, banqueting and reception halls will not be allowed to reopen until 1 July).  Banqueting and reception halls will be allowed to operate with a maximum of 50 people present.

type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: 03 June: In Belgium as of June 8th 2020, sporting events (organized and supervised by a person in charge) are limited to 20 people in June, subject to safety distances.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: In Belgium as of June 8th, leisure and free-time activities will be permitted.Cultural and leisure activities have to be organised in such a way as to avoid large gatherings. Wearing a mask is recommended at all times. Gatherings (e.g. village fairs, village festivals, etc.) are prohibited until 1 August and may then be resumed gradually.

type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description:
In Belgium performances with an audience - including cinemas - can be resumed from 1 July, but only subject to specific rules regarding crowd management, such as respecting the safety distance in the audience and a maximum of 200 attendees.
Activities should be organised in such a way as to avoid gatherings of too many people, e.g. outside the venue.  When people take part in cultural and leisure activities, wearing a mask is recommended at all times.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

Belgium, 27 July: From Wednesday 29 July and for at least four weeks (until the end of August): Telework is strongly recommended where possible to avoid too much contact between colleagues.
